name: Baracoa Anole
description: It has a large, pointed head and a long, whip-like tail. Predominantly green, it features a yellow pattern on the head, neck, and shoulders, especially pronounced in males.
image_alt: Baracoa anole, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 50–55 cm, with 60% being the tail; males are larger than females
reproduction: Females lay 1–2 eggs several times per season; incubation at 28°C lasts about two months.
attractions: It mostly stays high in trees and excels at climbing even smooth trunks. Living in pairs, males are territorial, marking their territory with conspicuous behavior—raising their heads and inflating their throat dewlaps.
breeding: The first two anoles were brought to the zoo in 1989 directly from Cuba by zoo staff. More consistent breeding began in 2007 with the acquisition of two males, joined by a female in 2010. The first offspring hatched in 2011, some of which still live at the zoo. By 2013, 17 young had hatched.
